definition: Wu dialects (spoken primarily in Shanghai and surrounding areas)
surname Wu/area comprising southern Jiangsu, northern Zhejiang and Shanghai/name of states in Southern China at different historical periods
dialect/language/speech
to tell to

sentences.english: This feature accords with the fact that Wu dialects are approaching to a verb-final type.
sentences.chinese: 這與吳語正在接近動詞居末類型的事實是相和諧的。

sentences.english: Mont scholars in Chinese dialectology believe that the northern border of ancient Wu dialect is Huai River.
sentences.chinese: 漢語方言學界一般認爲古吳語北至淮河流域。

sentences.english: This thesis mainly discusses the post-positions of Suichang dialect, a Wu dialect.
sentences.chinese: 本文集中討論吳語遂昌話的後置成分。

sentences.english: These characteristics are closely near with the three personal pronouns of modern Wu dialect.
sentences.chinese: 這些特徵已和現代吳語的三身代詞相近。

sentences.english: Most scholars in Chinese dialectology believe that the northern border of ancient Wu dialect is Huai River.
sentences.chinese: 漢語方言學界一般認爲古吳語北至淮河流域。

definition: entering tone/checked tone/one of the four tones of Middle Chinese
phonetic change
"officialese"/bureaucratic language/Mandarin
the four tones of Middle Chinese: level tone 平聲|平声, rising tone 上聲|上声, departing tone 去聲|去声 and entering tone 入聲|入声/the four tones of Modern Standard Mandarin
tone/note/a tone (on a Chinese syllable)/CL:個|个[ge4]
pronunciation/literary (rather than colloquial) pronunciation of a Chinese character
level or even tone/first and second tones in modern Mandarin
Guangfeng county in Shangrao 上饒|上饶, Jiangxi
Min dialects, spoken in Fujian Province, Taiwan etc
high and level tone, the first tone of putonghua
syllable
common saying/proverb/colloquial speech
music/rhyme and rhythm/initial, 音[yin1], and final and tone, 韻|韵[yun4], of a Chinese character/phoneme
nursery rhyme
rime dictionary (ancient type of Chinese dictionary that collates characters by tone and rhyme rather than by radical)
the final of a Chinese syllable (the component of a syllable remaining after removal of the initial consonant, if any, and the tone, e.g. the final of "niáng" is "iang")
